data.title: 15 Fantastic Things to Do in Key Largo
data.meta_description: Plan your Key Largo getaway with our website's recommendations for activities, dining, and more. Start your adventure today!
data.text:
In the most northern part of the Florida Keys, Key Largo nestles as a sunny paradise.

Key Largo is famous for its beautiful coral reefs, clear waters, and vibrant marine life. It offers a lot of fun activities for visitors of all ages.

What’s more, Key Largo is neighbors with Tavernier, Plantation Key, and Islamorada, which are full of adventure as well!

Whether you're a nature fan, water sports lover, or history buff, there's something for everyone to enjoy.

Here's a detailed travel guide on the top 15 fun things to do in Key Largo and its nearby areas.

1. Hang out with wildlife at the Crocodile Lake National Wildlife Refuge

10750 County Rd 905, Key Largo, FL 33037

Image from Flickr by Scott Beazley

The Crocodile Lake Wildlife Refuge is over 6,700 acres of lush mangrove forests and diverse environments. It serves as a crucial habitat for the American crocodile, which is listed as a threatened species.

Additionally, it provides a home for numerous bird species, including the at-risk Schaus' swallowtail butterfly.

Visitors can explore the refuge through guided tours, hikes, and informative programs. They can learn about its importance in conservation efforts and the unique animal life it supports.

2. Make a side trip to Everglades National Park

40001 State Hwy 9336, Homestead, FL 33034

Shutterstock Image

Everglades National Park is about forty-five minutes northwest of Key Largo, and it’s definitely worth your time.

The park is a vast and diverse area well-known for its unique environment. Covering over 1.5 million acres, Everglades National Park is the largest tropical wilderness of any kind in the United States.

The park is home to a wide array of wildlife, including alligators, panthers, and manatees. This makes it a haven for nature lovers and wildlife photographers alike.

Visitors can explore its marshes, mangroves, and sawgrass prairies via hiking trails, canoeing routes, and airboat tours.

Everglades National Park is not only a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It also serves as a crucial buffer against hurricanes and a vital source of freshwater for South Florida.

Oh, and don’t forget to take Shaka Guide with ya when you go! Check out our Everglades National Park Tour.

3. Snorkel over the Christ of the Abyss Statue at John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park

Mile Marker 102.5 Overseas Highway Key Largo FL 33037

Image from Flickr by David Smith

John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park is the first underwater park in the United States.

Covering about 70 nautical square miles, it is famous for its vibrant coral reefs and diverse marine life.

The area also boasts untouched underwater ecosystems, drawing visitors from around the world.

Visitors can enjoy:

swimming

scuba diving

glass-bottom boat tours, and

kayaking

But one of the most unique activities is snorkeling over the Christ of the Abyss statue.

Italian sculptor Guido Galletti created the original statue. He placed it in the Mediterranean Sea near the Italian Riviera in 1954.

Following its fame and importance as a symbol of peace and protection for divers, many copies were made.

Italian dive equipment maker Egidi Cressi donated one of these copies. They donated it to the Underwater Society of America in 1961.

It was then placed in the John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park in 1965, becoming a popular diving spot.

This statue of bronze sits among lively coral reefs and abundant marine life. It’s a really magical experience!

4. See what’s bitin’ on a guided deep-sea fishing trip

Islamorada, located about 20 minutes south of Key Largo on the Overseas Highway, earns its reputation as the Sport Fishing Capital of the World.

If you’re ready to get out on the deep blue sea and catch some dinner, there are several places to do it!

These are some of our favorites:

Bud N' Mary's Marina

(79851 Overseas Hwy, Islamorada, FL 33036)

Bud N' Mary's Marina

Bud N' Mary's Marina is one of the oldest and most famous fishing marinas in the Florida Keys.

They offer a variety of deep-sea fishing charters targeting species like sailfish, marlin, tuna, and mahi-mahi.

Key Largo Offshore Fishing

(528 Caribbean Dr, Key Largo, FL 33037)

Sea Spirit

This charter company provides deep-sea fishing trips customized to your choice and skill level.

Whether you're a novice or an experienced angler, their captains can guide you to productive fishing grounds.

You can target species like snapper, grouper, and amberjack under their expert guidance.

Miss Chief Charters

(400 Ocean Dr, Key Largo, FL 33037)

Chief Charters offers deep-sea fishing trips led by experienced local captains.

They focus on catching big game fish such as sailfish, tuna, and kingfish.

This promises an exciting adventure on the open waters of the Atlantic Ocean.

Robbie's of Islamorada

77522 Overseas Hwy, Islamorada, FL 33036)

Robbie's Marina offers deep-sea fishing charters leaving from Islamorada. Their experienced captains can take you to prime fishing spots for a chance to catch trophy fish such as swordfish, wahoo, and grouper.

5. Discover local favorites at the Florida Keys Visitor Center

106240 Overseas Highway Key Largo, FL 33037

Visit Florida

Immerse yourself in the natural wonders and cultural heritage of the Florida Keys!

The Florida Keys Visitor Center offers displays and exhibits about the unique ecosystems, wildlife, and history of the area. It provides learning opportunities for all ages.

Visitors can learn about conservation efforts, marine life, and the importance of protecting the delicate balance of the Florida Keys ecosystem.

The center provides maps, brochures, and expert advice to help visitors plan outdoor adventures. These adventures include snorkeling, diving, kayaking, and fishing in the nearby area.

6. Take a cruise on the African Queen

99701 Overseas Hwy, Key Largo, FL 33037

Shutterstock Image

Visitors can step back in time and experience the charm of the iconic African Queen.

This historic vessel, made famous by the 1951 film of the same name starring Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn. It offers scenic cruises along the beautiful waterways of the Florida Keys.

As guests step aboard the carefully restored steam-powered boat, they are taken to an era of adventure and romance. They cruise through mangrove-lined channels and turquoise waters.

Knowledgeable guides share interesting stories about the boat's history and its Hollywood connections, adding depth to the journey.

7. Take a guided kayak tour with Mangroves and Manatees Eco Tours

90311 Old Hwy. Tavernier, Fl 33070

Image by Mangroves and Manatees Eco Tours

Have you ever kayaked before? Well, even if the answer is no, this tour will definitely be one you’ve never experienced!

Mangroves and Manatees Eco Tours in Tavernier, Florida, offers a learning experience exploring the unique ecosystems of the Florida Keys.

Led by experienced guides, you can expect to paddle kayaks through winding mangrove tunnels. Here, you’ll learn about the importance of these coastal forests as nurseries for marine life.

The tours also provide opportunities to see gentle manatees in their natural habitat. Additionally, guests may spot other native wildlife such as dolphins, sea turtles, and various bird species during the trip.

You can enjoy encounters while gaining insight into their behaviors and conservation efforts.

With small group sizes and individualized attention, Mangroves and Manatees Eco Tours offer a memorable experience.

They provide an environmentally friendly way to discover the beauty and biodiversity of the Florida Keys' marine environment.

8. Swim with dolphins at Dolphins Plus Bayside

101900 Overseas Hwy, Key Largo, FL 33037

Image by Dolphin Plus

Dolphins Plus Bayside offers some pretty memorable experiences focused on being with dolphins.

Visitors can take part in swims with dolphins. During these experiences, they have the chance to swim, play, and even receive a dorsal fin ride!

Guests can also learn about dolphin behavior, physiology, and conservation efforts through hands-on activities and educational talks.

And, Dolphins Plus Bayside provides programs for those who prefer to admire these amazing creatures from a distance. These programs offer insights into their natural behaviors in a controlled environment.

9. Explore the local art scene at Rain Barrel Village

Image by Rain Barrel Village

Art lovers notice this art community for its iconic rain barrels decorated with colorful murals. They display local artists' skills and act as both practical water collectors and attention-grabbing landmarks.

With its beautiful waterfront views and diverse atmosphere, Rain Barrel Village offers a typical Florida Keys experience.

Visitors invite themselves to dive into the region's varied culture while enjoying its beautiful natural surroundings.

10. Feed the Tarpon at Robbie’s of Islamorada

77522 Overseas Hwy, Islamorada, FL 33036

Tarpons are large, ancient-looking fish known for their incredible strength and impressive leaps out of the water.

At Robbie's, visitors can buy buckets of fish to feed these impressive creatures from the docks. This creates a memorable sight as the tarpon swarm and competes for tasty treats.

As the fish thrash and leap, visitors can feel the excitement and adrenaline rush. They experience the thrill of being in such close contact with these impressive creatures.

Located in the heart of the Florida Keys, Robbie's offers a unique opportunity to connect with nature.

Visitors can observe these remarkable fish in their natural habitat, leaving them with memories that will last a lifetime.

11. Experience a moment of zen and pie at the Blonde Giraffe Key Lime Pie Factory

92220 Overseas Hwy, Tavernier, FL 33070

The Blond Giraffe Key Lime Pie Factory is a charming spot. It offers a sensory experience that combines the tangy sweetness of key lime pies with the serene beauty of a zen garden.

At the factory, visitors can watch as skilled artisans handcraft these iconic pies with care. They make them using a traditional Key Lime pie recipe that’s been passed down through generations.

Surrounding the factory is a peaceful zen garden, where visitors can relax and unwind amidst lush greenery.

The garden has flowing water and carefully placed stones, creating a calm spot in the heart of the Keys.

The combination of delicious key lime pies and the peaceful atmosphere of the zen garden makes the Blond Giraffe Key Lime Pie Factory a must-visit destination.

It's perfect for anyone seeking a taste of Florida's delicious food and a moment of peace in their travels.

12. Sip a Rum Runner at the Holiday Isle Tiki Bar

84001 Overseas Hwy, Islamorada, FL 33036

Image from Flickr by Don Johnson 395

The Rum Runner cocktail is said to have been invented in the 1950s at the Holiday Isle Tiki Bar in Islamorada, Florida.

As the story goes, the bartender was expecting a new shipment of liquor and needed to make space for it.

So, he mixed up a blend of leftovers, including various rums and tropical fruit juices.

The drink quickly gained popularity due to its deliciously fruity flavor. It also became known for its potent kick, eventually becoming a signature drink of the Florida Keys.

The original recipe typically includes:

light rum

dark rum

blackberry liqueur

banana liqueur

grenadine

orange juice, and

pineapple juice

...shaken with ice and served in a glass topped with a pineapple wedge and cherry.

Over time, the Rum Runner has become a beloved classic cocktail synonymous with the laid-back, tropical vibe of the Florida Keys. These days, the Holiday Isle Tiki Bar is located inside the Postcard Inn Beach Resort.

13. Hang out with marine mammals at Theater of the Sea

84721 Overseas Hwy, Islamorada, FL 33036

Did you know that nurse sharks like belly rubs? You can learn more facts like this at Theater of the Sea in Islamorada.

Theater of the Sea is a premier marine mammal park and family-friendly attraction that offers an engaging and educational experience with marine life.

Visitors can marvel at the captivating dolphin, sea lion, and parrot shows.

Highly trained animals displays their intelligence and agility in a series of entertaining performances, creating memorable experiences for viewers.

Beyond the shows, guests have the opportunity to swim alongside dolphins, sea lions, and sharks in a safe and supervised environment.

The park also features beautifully landscaped gardens, providing a serene setting for strolls and photo opportunities.

With its commitment to conservation and education, Theater of the Sea offers visitors of all ages a memorable and enriching experience.

It fosters a deeper appreciation for the wonders of the ocean and its inhabitants, leaving a lasting impact on those who visit.

14. Go Birdwatching at Laura Quinn Bird Sanctuary

93600 Overseas Hwy, Tavernier, FL 33070

Shutterstock Image

The Laura Quinn Bird Sanctuary stands as a tribute to the passion and dedication of Laura Quinn. She was a remarkable environmentalist and bird lover whose legacy lives on through this sanctuary.

Born and raised in the Florida Keys, Quinn developed a deep love and appreciation for the region's natural beauty from an early age.

Throughout her life, she tirelessly promoted for the protection of bird habitats. She recognized the vital role these environments play in supporting biodiversity.

Inspired by her vision, the sanctuary was created to provide a safe haven for native and migratory bird species. It offers a peaceful refuge amidst the busy surroundings, honoring Quinn's commitment to avian conservation.

Quinn's legacy lives on through the sanctuary. It serves as a reminder of the significant impact individuals can have on conservation efforts and the lasting beauty of the natural world.

Today, visitors can explore the sanctuary's trails and observe a myriad of bird species. This pays homage to Laura Quinn's lasting legacy and commitment to environmental protection.

15. Take a leisurely stroll on the Overseas Heritage Trail

Shutterstock Image

The Overseas Heritage Trail follows the route of the historic Overseas Railroad. This railroad was built by Henry Flagler in the early 20th century.

This iconic trail runs the length of the Overseas Highway from Key Largo to Key West—which is about 106 miles!

Although some parts of the trail have deteriorated due to age and weather, large sections of it are open for walking, running, hiking, and biking!

The trail offers stunning views of the turquoise waters of the Florida Keys. Along the way, you can see remains of the old railroad bridges and learn about the trail's rich history at various educational sites.

Additionally, the trail provides access to many parks, beaches, and areas for leisure activities, such as picnicking, swimming, snorkeling, and fishing.

Whether you're seeking excitement, relaxation, or a trip through history, the Overseas Heritage Trail promises an unforgettable experience.

It highlights the natural beauty and cultural heritage of the Florida Keys, offering something for every type of traveler to enjoy.

Explore Key Largo with the Shaka Guide

Visiting Key Largo? Check out Shaka Guide’s Overseas Highway & Florida Keys tour!

This audio tour guide takes you from Key West to Key Largo (or vice-versa) making stops along the way!

You’ll explore the tropical beauty of southern Florida with a guide by your side.

Ready to take the tour? Check out Shaka Guide's Overseas Highway & Florida Keys Tour!

We hope that we’ve given you all the information you need to make the most of your day. Your vacation is extremely important to us so if you have any questions feel free to reach out at aloha@shakaguide.com.

For more detailed information to help you plan, check out our Overseas Highway & Florida Keys Itinerary and Know Before You Go article.
